title-group.article-title: Perceived Parental Attachment, Personality Characteristics, and Cognition in Male Incest

abstract.p: The aim of this study was to investigate the multiple pathways of perceived child-rearing practices, cognitive-executive functions, and personality characteristics in incest and other sexual offenders. The participants consisted of 217 male sexual offenders who were in custody in southern Taiwan. Participants were divided into two groups of 25 incest and 192 nonincest sexual offenders. The incest offenders tended to be less extraverted and worse in abstract reasoning ability, and to have more perseverative thinking, and perceived less parental care than other sexual offenders. Moreover, the structural equation model showed that the effect of parental care on the type of sexual offense is mediated by cognitive-executive functions and personality traits. This finding suggests that the personality traits, cognitive function, and parental attachment of incest offenders differ from other sexual offenders. This result can be a helpful reference in sexual-offender intervention programs for relapse prevention.

body.p: The statistics of the Ministry of Justice in Taiwan showed that from 2001 to 2006, an average of 3,209 new sexual-offense cases were brought to court each year. In 2006, there were 1.6 times more persons found guilty than that in 2001 (Ministry of Justice, 2006). Sexual crime can cause the victim physical and psychological trauma and also has lifetime effects on the self-image and interpersonal trust of the victim. Some victims even become perpetrators and start to sexually assault others (Glasser et al., 2001; Lambie, Seymour, Lee, & Adams, 2002; Noll, 2005). Therefore, the prevention of sexual offenses has been a continuous focus of public safety. According to the Criminal Code in Taiwan, and beginning in 1994, all sexual offenders must complete mandatory treatment programs before being paroled or released from prison. As there are no specialized sexual-offender prisons in Taiwan, prisons have to contract with the psychiatric departments in local hospitals for mandatory sexual-offender treatment (Lung, Lu, & Wei, 2001). However, even though psychiatry evaluation, treatment, and relapse prevention for sexual offenders have been given attention in Taiwan, the integrated rule and treatment model for sexual offenders is still insufficient when compared with the United States and European countries. Taiwanese sexual offenders do not volunteer to participate in these treatment programs, thus, difficulties have been experienced in their execution (Lung et al., 2005, 2007).

Gacono, Meloy, and Bridges (2000) found that the inner world of sexual offenders is fairly anxiety ridden and that they often have difficulties in their interaction with the external world. Six months before the commission of the crime, sexual offenders often have adjustment, alcohol, and illegal drug-use problems (Pithers, Kashima, Cumming, Beal, & Buell, 1988), and most sex offenders have previous convictions (Groth, 1979), antisocial personality tendencies, or other mental problems (Kopp, 1962). Further research has indicated that the self-regulation pathways that lead to sexual offending are differentially associated with offender types (Yates & Kingston, 2006). Incest offenders were less psychopathic (Firestone, Bradford, Greenberg, & Serran, 2000; Lung & Huang, 2004; Olver & Wong, 2006; Valliant, Gauthier, Pottier, & Kosmyna, 2000), more concerned with interpersonal social values (Valliant et al., 2000), and had a lower rate of recidivism (Doren, 2002) than other sexual offenders. The aforementioned studies also showed that the personality of the sexual offender differs from that of other people and that different types of sexual offenders may have different social-psychological characteristics.

However, much research has shown that early parent–child attachment will influence the development of an individual’s personality (Bowlby, 1977; Lu, Shu, Chang, & Lung, 2006; Lung, Lin, Lu, & Shu, 2004), and personality characteristics are the main factors influencing a person’s behavioral characteristics and styles of coping (Y. C. Lu et al., 2006; Lung et al., 2004). These concepts have also been demonstrated in studies on criminal behavior. Studies have shown that early attachment experiences are closely related to sexual-assault behavior, and insecure attachments in childhood lead to adult sexual offending (Marshall, 1989; Smallbone & Dadds, 2000). Another study on parental disciplining has shown that there is a clear disparity in parental rejection, paternal ambivalence, and maternal strictness between young people who commit crimes and those who do not (Patterson & Snyder, 1987). Moreover, a high percentage of sexual offenders grow up with overprotective and controlling parents (Su, 1971). These studies reveal that parental upbringing has a very close relationship with and influence on the individual’s personality characteristics and behavioral norms.

Marshall (1996) demonstrated that sexual offenders suffer greatly from deficits in cognitive functions and personality. Marshall and Marshall (2000) further suggested that poor parent–child attachment produces cognitive and affective deficits. This in turn leads to the use of sex as a coping strategy and the lack of inhibition in deviant sexual fantasizing due to anger. One study has shown that 50% of sexual offenders have demonstrated executive-function deficits in neurological–psychological assessments (Graber, Hartmann, Coffman, Huey, & Golden, 1982). Another study pointed out that recidivists do not exhibit flexibility in thinking, and they are less likely to process information and are more inclined to act without thinking of the consequences (Valliant, Freeston, Pottier, & Kosmyna, 2003).

Executive function is the cognitive construct used to describe behaviors thought to be mediated by the frontal lobes (Duncan, 1986). It encompasses modulating, impulsive, responding, and problem-solving abilities (Heaton, Chelune, Talley, Kay, & Curtiss, 1993); is correlated with personality dimensions (Gurrera, Nestor, O’Donnell, Rosenberg, & McCarley, 2005); and is considered necessary for socially appropriate adult conduct (Lezak, 1995). Therefore, the frontal lobes are thought to play an important role in the inhibition of behavior (Gorenstein, 1982). Frontal lobe damages in patients may cause distinct personality changes (Stuss & Benson, 1984). In addition, several studies have indicated that cognitive performance varies with individual differences in personality traits, such as the different arousal levels for introverts and extraverts (Beauducel, Brocke, & Leue, 2006; Brocke & Battmann, 1992; Eysenck, 1967, 1981). The variation in several personality dimensions are predicted in the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) performance (Tien, Costa, & Eaton, 1992).

The above studies offered evidence of the paired association between parent–child attachment, individual cognitive functions, and personality, but the multiple pathways of these three dimensions are still unclear. To integrate the previous literature reviews, a formulation is schematically represented in Figure 1. The figure shows that parent–child attachment, individual sociodemographics (age, education, marital status, substance use, and previous convictions), cognition, and personality have a direct impact on different types of sexual offense. Moreover, the effects of parent–child attachment on the type of sexual offense are mediated by the individual’s cognitive functions and personality. This study has hypothesized a recursive model of cognitive functions and personality having influence on each other.

body.p: Previous studies on the parental attachment, cognitive function, and personality traits of sexual offenders have focused on the comparison between sexual offenders and nonsexual offenders (Craissati, McClurg, & Browne, 2002; Graber et al., 1982; Patterson & Snyder, 1987; Su, 1971; Valliant et al., 2003), but there is a lack of studies focusing on incest offenders. Therefore, the current study investigated sexual offenders from the perspectives of finding risk factors in psychosocial characteristics and the multiple pathways of the differences between incest and other sexual offenders in parent–child attachment, cognitive functions, and personality characteristics.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants in this study were 238 male sexual offenders who were imprisoned in southern Taiwan between September 1999 and March 2005. In all, 217 participants (91.18%) out of 238 participants agreed to being evaluated by our trained field-workers. Of the 217 participants, 25 were incest offenders and 192 were not. All participants had committed the sexual offense of rape, and incest was defined as when the victim and the sexual offender were of familial relationship (16 biological children, 2 stepchildren, 6 nieces, and 1 sibling), excluding those who were pedophiles. The diagnosis and exclusion of pedophilia was performed by a psychiatrist using the Chinese version of the Structured Clinical Interview for Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (3rd ed., revised; DSM-III-R; American Psychiatric Association, 1987; SCID; Chen & Ku, 1993).

sec.title: Parental Bonding Inventory (PBI)
sec.p: The PBI was developed by Parker, Tupling, and Brown in 1979. It has shown good construct and predictive validity in measuring actual parenting rather than perceived parenting (Parker, 1989, 1990; Parker et al., 1979) and is uninfluenced by mood states (Parker, 1989). The Chinese version was written and revised in 1999 (Shu, Lo, & Lung, 1999). The PBI was designed as a refined self-report measure of the dimensions of care and protection. The questionnaire instructed the participants to rate how their parents treated them during the first 16 years of their lives. Of the 25 items in the questionnaire, 12 assessed parental care and 13 assessed parental protection. The Cronbach’s alpha was .65 to .73, and the test–retest reliability was .66 to .88 (Shu et al., 1999).

sec.title: Eysenck Personality Questionnaire (EPQ)
sec.p: The EPQ was developed theoretically based on personality traits (Eysenck & Eysenck, 1975). Its Chinese version was provided by L. Lu in 1994. The EPQ is composed of two major personality traits of extraversion and neuroticism (Depue & Collins, 1999; Plomin, DeFries, McClearn, & McGuffin, 2001), with 14 and 11 items each. Higher scores tend to reveal higher levels of extraversion and neuroticism. Those who are extraverted are more sociable and impulsive, and those who are neurotic are more anxious and emotional (Plomin et al., 2001). The EPQ demonstrated a Cronbach’s alpha of .90 and good validity (L. Lu, 1994).

sec.title: WCST
sec.p: The WCST is a clinical neuropsychological instrument. It was originally developed to assess abstract reasoning ability and the ability to shift cognitive strategies in response to changing environmental contingencies (Grant & Berg, 1948). The WCST was computerized by Tien et al. in 1996 to avoid different results from different testers. It was performed according to the standardized criteria of Heaton et al. (1993). The participants were given a pack of 128 response cards and told to match each response card with one of the stimulus cards. After matching 10 cards using the first sorting category (color), the participants shifted to the second category (form), and then to the third (number). The procedure was repeated twice, until the participants completed six categories or until all 128 response cards were used. In this study, the WCST indices consisted of conceptual level responses (CLR), failure to maintain set (FMS), percentage of nonperseverative errors (PNPE), and percentage of perseverative errors (PPE). CLR represents the ability to think abstractly; higher scores in this index indicated a better performance. FMS is related to the ability to maintain the cognitive set; higher scores represent worse task persistence. PNPE refers to response errors made not because of perseverance, and PPE represents flexibility in thinking; higher scores in these two indices indicated a worse performance (Heaton et al., 1993).

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: Approval was first obtained from the institutional review board at the Kaohsiung Armed Forces General Hospital in southern Taiwan. After giving detailed informed consent, all participants completed the questionnaires that include demographic information (age, education, marital status, substance use, and previous convictions), the PBI and EPQ, and the WCST carried out by a psychologist.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data were analyzed using the SPSS version 10.0 for Windows software package and the AMOS 5.0 statistical software package. Demographic characteristics were examined using the Student’s t test for age and education. The chi-square test was used to evaluate the other demographic characteristics between the two groups. Logistic regression analysis was used to investigate the relationships between the groups and explore the predictive factors for different types of sexual offenses. As the findings from regression analysis can only provide us with an idea of the precipitating factors, and the predisposing factors are often hidden, Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) analysis was used to understand the contextual relationship of the variables. The substantive use of SEM has been growing in the fields of psychology and the social sciences. SEM integrates random effects, factors, and latent class analysis in both cross-sectional and longitudinal settings, and for both single-level and multilevel data, and has a comprehensive means for assessing and modifying theoretical models (Bentler, 1983; Browne, 1984; Joreskog, 1978). Hence, SEM was used to examine the multiple pathways among these measures and the demographic characteristics.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The demographic data of the participants are shown in Table 1. The ages of patients in the two groups were statistically significantly different (t = −2.07, p = .046). In terms of marital status, 11 participants in the incest group were divorced (44%) and 119 nonincest participants were not married (62%). No statistical significance was found in cigarette, alcohol and illegal drug use, education, and previous convictions between the two groups.

For personality characteristics, there was a significant difference between the two groups in extraversion (t = 2.67, p = .008). No significant difference was found between parental attachment and cognitive function in the two groups (Table 2).

sec.title: Logistic Regression Analysis
sec.p: Our study used logistic regression analysis to investigate whether age, education, marital status, substance use, previous convictions, parental attachment, personality characteristics, and executive functions are risk factors for becoming incest offenders. The result showed that demographic characteristics and all indices of the PBI and WCST were not related to sexual assault. However, the extraversion trait in the EPQ was a protective factor in avoiding incest. Sexual offenders who are more extraverted are less likely to be incest offenders (Table 3).

sec.title: Structural Equation Model
sec.p: Although we found a risk factor for incest in the logistic regression results, we wished to further clarify the impact each factor had by using SEM. Figure 2 shows the multiple pathways among extraversion, abstract thinking ability, perseverative thinking, and parental attachment. This model resulted in a goodness of fit (GFI) of more than .9 and a p value of more than .05 (χ2 = 5.422, p = .579, adjusted GFI index [AGFI] = .973). Thus, the results suggested that the observed data in this study were compatible with the null model.

caption.p: The parsimonious structural model of maternal bonding, extraversion, and abstract reasoning ability in incest and nonincest sexual offenders

Note: Several of the parameters were constrained to enable estimation. Circles represent residuals or disturbance terms for each variable. Dummy variables of “incest”: 1 refers to incest sexual offenders, 0 refers to nonincest sexual offenders.

sec.p: In the final model in the parental-attachment aspect, paternal care had a positive direct effect on the participant’s extraversion trait (β = .16, p = .014) and maternal care had a positive direct effect on the participant’s abstract thinking ability (β = .23, p < .001), had an indirect effect on the patient’s perseverative thinking response (β = −.77, p < 10−6), and further affected the patient’s extraversion trait (β = −.27; p < 10−4); in addition, extraversion had a direct effect on the type of sexual offense (β = −.18; p = .007). In other words, the incest offenders in this study are less extraverted and more perseverative in thinking, have a worse abstract thinking ability, and perceived less parental care in childhood and the teenage period (Figure 2).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Studies have found that 85% of sexual offenders meet the diagnostic criteria for substance-abuse disorder (Dunsieth et al., 2004), and 6 months prior to conviction, there are often alcohol and illegal drug-use problems (Pithers et al., 1988). This study found that even though there is no difference between incest and nonincest sexual offenders in cigarette, alcohol, and illegal drug use, the majority of sexual offenders are cigarette and alcohol users (60%-88%), thus, showing that these are common issues among sexual offenders.

The majority of nonincest sexual offenders were not married, and the majority of incest offenders were divorced. This is consistent with Westermeyer’s (1978) much earlier results that incest offenders were mostly divorced and their sexual partner had passed away or they were separated. In addition, sexual offenders are not satisfied with the sexual relationship with their partner, or even feel humiliated by it, thus diminishing their masculine dignity, which is why they turn to their daughters or other female relative to fulfill their satisfaction (Lung & Huang, 2004).

Most studies on the parent–child attachment, cognitive functions, and personality traits of sexual offenders have compared sexual offenders with nonsexual offenders (Craissati et al., 2002; Graber et al., 1982; Patterson & Snyder, 1987; Su, 1971; Valliant et al., 2003). There is a lack of studies that focus on the difference between incest and nonincest sexual offenders. Shu, Chang, and Lung (2001), in their parental-attachment study in Taiwan, found that the average paternal-care score within one standard deviation was 14.87 ~ 27.01, paternal protection was 5.57 ~ 17.31, maternal care was 19.74 ~ 29.78, and maternal protection was 6.60 ~ 18.12. In this study, the PBI scores for most participants in both groups fell within these ranges, and there was no significant difference between the two groups. Thus, in the parental-attachment aspect, sexual offenders do not differ from normal people. Moreover, our study found that parental protection did not have an effect on cognitive functions and personality characteristics; instead, the main negative impact on these factors was the deficiency in parental care. This might imply that incest offenders, compared with nonincest offenders, perceived more neglect by their parents and the need for care not being fulfilled in childhood.

As for the multiple pathways of parent–child attachment, cognitive functions, and personality, in the sample of the current study, the results of the structural equation model revealed that less paternal care caused the offenders to be less extraverted and to have a greater tendency of being an incest offender. In addition, the effect of maternal care on individual personality was mediated by cognitive functions, such as abstract thinking ability and perseverative thinking. Therefore, participants who lacked maternal care when growing up have a worse abstract thinking ability, and their thinking is less flexible and more perseverative, which would further influence their personality traits in becoming less extraverted, and they would be more likely to become an incest-type sexual offender. Our results clearly demonstrated that parental caring and the individual’s cognitive functions are predisposing factors for incest offenders and that lower extraversion is a precipitating factor for this kind of criminal act. Furthermore, from the structural equation model, the results of this study revealed that cognitive functions and personality have a nonrecursive pathway relationship, which indicates that an individual’s cognitive functions can predict his personality traits. Shu, Tien, Lung, and Chang (2000) pointed out that the scores of the WCST were mostly age dependent and associated with underlying central nerve system (CNS) maturity level. In this study, the results revealed that CLR and PPE, which are both executive functions, have a nonrecursive effect, which indicates that the participants’ abstract thinking ability will affect their cognitive ability. This implies that the order of development of these brain functions needs to be clarified by further studies.

Studies have indicated that frontal-lobe damage may result in personality changes and problems in decision making and other executive functions; it is also associated with social impairments (Mesulam, 1986; Stuss & Benson, 1984). One study revealed that early-onset damage to the prefrontal cortex could impair the acquisition of complex social conventions and moral rules (Anderson, Bechare, Damasio, Tranel, & Damasio, 1999). These studies showed the relationship between the frontal lobe and social/moral behaviors. In addition, Milner (1963) noted that the frontal-lobe patients made significantly more perseverative errors in the WCST than nonfrontal control group, but these patients were unimpaired in terms of nonperseverative errors. Heaton et al. (1993) further indicated that perseverative error is a predictor for frontal-lobe pathological changes, which is also significantly related to antisocial behavior (Morgan & Lilienfeld, 2000). The aforementioned studies showed that damage to the frontal lobe might result in inflexible thinking and cause moral-rules impairment and further behavioral problems. The current study suggests that perseverative thinking (frontal lobe) is associated with a type of sexual offender and that nonperseverative errors (nonfrontal or unspecific cerebral area) have no significant association. Moreover, perseverative errors were found to be negatively correlated with an extraverted personality, which is consistent with the research of Gurrera et al. (2005). They found that perseverative responses and perseverative errors are both negatively correlated with extraversion, thereby showing that those who are more perseverative are less extraverted.

In 1981, Eysenck suggested that introversion and extraversion reflect individual differences in a cortical arousal system modulated by reticulothalamic–cortical pathways, and could influence cognitive performance in interaction with task parameters. Each dimension of personality shows different brain responses during cognitive activation paradigms, based on the model of personality conceived by Eysenck (Eysenck, 1981; Kumari, Ffytche, Williams, & Gray, 2004). Extraversion is associated with brain activity in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex, which link to the cognitive function. Hence, differences in personality trait could induce different brain responses during cognitive activity and provide a different neurobiological basis (Kumari et al., 2004).

The results of Lehne’s (1994) study revealed that sexual offenders have higher scores on neuroticism than the control sample, which shows that sexual offenders have higher levels of neurotic tendencies, such as anxiety, hostility, depression, self-consciousness, impulsiveness, and vulnerability, than normal people but without a statistically significant difference in the extraversion aspect. The present study found that in the neuroticism dimension, incest offenders did not differ from other sexual offenders. However, they tended to be less extraverted than other sexual offenders. Groth (1979) indicated that although sexual offenders differ in why they committed the act, power, anger, and sexuality are all included in their motivations. The power rapists seek to solve their problems through gaining power, domination, and control, and they see sexual assault as an act in which they can unfold their power and control. Applying this theory into our result that extraversion can be used to distinguish incest offenders from other sexual offenders, it may be that incest offenders are less extraverted; therefore, when they seek power and control, they target their own family members instead of strangers.

Factors that influence the effectiveness of sexual-offender treatment are an important issue and have been studied extensively. Several studies have indicated that therapist–client personality similarity (Coleman, 2006; Mendelsohn & Geller, 1963; Nelson & Stake, 1994) and client extraversion (Coleman, 2006; Nelson & Stake, 1994) are associated with the therapeutic alliance and suggested that intake personality matching may lead to decreased premature terminations and better outcomes in psychological treatment. Furthermore, a previous study found that completion of prison-based treatment can greatly decrease recidivism rates (Duwe & Goldman, 2009), and understanding the personality characteristics of these offenders will help therapists better build relationships with them, to increase therapy effectiveness. In addition, cognitive-behavioral therapy has been found to be effective in sexual-offender treatments (Marshall, Marshall, Serran, & O’Brien, 2008; Yates, 2003). This study found that there are differences in thought pattern between incest and nonincest sexual offenders; this can be used as references in cognitive therapies.

In addition to the findings and suggestions described above, there are also limitations to this study. The first limitation is that there were only 25 incest offenders, which is much less than the other sexual offenders in our sample. Previous studies have found that mothers of children who have been sexually abused often experience great distress and partner physical violence (Hebert, Daigneault, Collin-Vezina, & Cyr, 2007; Hiebert-Murphy, 1998, 2001). In addition, intrafamiliar sexual abuse is difficult to document because the safety of the child must be taken into consideration; children must be protected from additional abuse and coercion while attempting to preserve the family unit (Sakelliadis, Spiliopoulou, & Papadodima, 2009). Thus, reports of incest are much rarer than other sexual offenses and this case-number difference also reflects the difference in the prevalence of sexual-offence types. Second, we were unable to collect data on the age of the participant when committing the crime; therefore, we were unable to further investigate the relationship between commitment age and other variables in our study.

In brief, this study’s results revealed that individual personality traits, cognitive functions, and parent–child attachment have different effects on the incest and nonincest sexual offender. Therefore, when these offenders attend mandatory treatment, the treatment objective and planning should take the cognitive functions, personality traits, and other factors that are proximally related to sexual delinquency into consideration or even take into consideration distal factors or other indirect factors, such as parental attachment in childhood and the teenage years. The results of this study can be used as a reference for therapists to establish an appropriate relapse-prevention treatment model for sexual offenders, to decrease premature terminations, and to enhance the effectiveness of treatment.
